Award.AwardTitle: Maturation of an S-STEM Scholarship program at a Hispanic Serving/Minority Serving Institution

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The S-STEM program at California State University-San Bernardino (CSUSB), known as Mathematics and Science Scholars (MASS), promotes the success of a diverse group of academically talented, financially needy students in six STEM departments, by building on an established scholarship program. Specifically, the MASS program offers 26 annual academic scholarships to students of high academic potential and financial need, enrolled in the Departments of Biology, Chemistry and Biochemistry, Geological Sciences, Mathematics, and Physics, as well as in the School of Computer Science and Engineering. Students are recruited from among top high school graduates, as well as top transfer applicants, through established partnerships among the College of Natural Sciences, the Office of Recruitment & Admissions, and the Office of Financial Aid. MASS scholarship recipients receive academic and career support provided by MASS faculty and staff personnel and others, including those of CoyoteCareers, McNair Scholars, and LSAMP. Successful students continue as Scholars after quarterly review, while priority registration in courses and opportunities for research and internships facilitate retention and graduation. As over 70% of CSUSB students are the first in their families to go to college, the assigned personal disciplinary mentor and co-curricular experiences are vital to the Scholars' academic progress and development as professionals. Since MASS Scholars are recruited from the economically and educationally disadvantaged population of Inland Southern California, the program serves an important role in preparing much needed STEM leaders in the region.

Specific objectives of MASS are to:

1) Recruit new freshmen and transfer students each year, in order to maintain 26 Scholars, as well as additional equally talented students without financial need.

2) Provide mentors (faculty mentors in their disciplines) to Scholars, in addition to cohort-specific academic support services in order to promote the Scholars' continued academic success.

3) Offer co-curricular activities to develop MASS students as scientists, mathematicians, engineers and STEM teachers, including MASS-sponsored events, Departmental and College research seminars, attendance at local or other scientific conferences, participation in the seminar series sponsored by CoyoteCareers, and opportunities to participate in STEM research.

4) Graduate well-prepared candidates for employment in STEM fields, or for graduate study in STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The California State University San Bernardino (CSUSB) S-STEM program had the following goal: 

To promote the success of a diverse group of academically talented, financially needy students in six STEM departments, by building on the established S-STEM program. 

To achieve this goal, we executed the following objectives:

  • Recruit freshmen and transfer students each year, in order to maintain 26 NSF-funded scholars
  • Provide mentor and cohort support, and academic support services necessary to promote the scholars’ continued academic success
  • Promote co-curricular activities to develop these students as scientists, mathematicians and engineers.
  • Graduate well-prepared candidates for employment in STEM fields, or for graduate study in STEM disciplines

Intellectual merit: The sum total of the program: (1) recruiting cohorts of students with majors in biology, chemistry/biochemistry, geological sciences, mathematics, computer science/engineering, and physics; (2) providing pro-active, one on one mentoring with a designated faculty advisor in each STEM discipline; (3) providing quality co-curricular opportunities including career preparation, internships, and research; and (4) providing support when necessary, has been highly successful in promoting student success and graduation at CSUSB. Of the 55 total scholars supported by this grant, 44 have already graduated (78%) at rates much faster and higher than the general CSUSB STEM population: 86% of our transfer scholars graduated in 4 years or less (compared to 60% in the College of Natural Sciences), and 94% of our freshman scholars graduated in 5 years or less (compared to 12.6% for all STEM majors on campus). Many of our scholars have met these benchmarks while also earning a minor, a second major, or a teaching credential. Keys to our success have been high student involvement: scholars participated in an average of over 2.5 co-curricular STEM activities per quarter, which is very high for students on a commuter campus like ours. In addition, the peer support and faculty mentors were vital in promoting student progress. The attached word map image summarizes the most common words from our five annual evaluation exit interviews and focus groups.

Broader impact:

The Inland Empire (IE) of Southern California is a vast, populous, and highly socially, economically, and educationally disadvantaged region of the State and the U.S. As a Minority and Hispanic-Serving Institution, and home to nearly 80% first generation college students, CSUSB provides opportunities for upward mobility for our students and our region. This S-STEM award supported 55 scholars, with 45 graduates to date, and three continuing students, poised to become STEM leaders in the region. Of the graduates, about half started their educations at community colleges, and over 40% are now pursing graduate degrees in STEM or related disciplines. Sixty percent of graduates are employed in STEM industries, mostly in the region. Eight graduates are teaching high school or college-level STEM courses, further supporting the education of the next generation of IE citizens. These 44 new graduates join 30 graduates supported by a prior S-STEM award to CSUSB, and lessons learned from past programs have prepared us for our new large S-STEM collaborative award between four regional community colleges and CSUSB, that will continue to provide talented science, mathematics and engineering graduates for the region.
